docs.snippet: WITH civilian governments now the rule rather than the exception, Latin America's armies have to find new things to do. Counterinsurgency operations against foreign-supported guerrillas, a unifying mission since the 1950's, have faded with the decay...
docs.lead_paragraph: WITH civilian governments now the rule rather than the exception, Latin America's armies have to find new things to do. Counterinsurgency operations against foreign-supported guerrillas, a unifying mission since the 1950's, have faded with the decay of Cuba and the Soviet Union. Border disputes, long a pretext for maintaining standing armies, are increasingly papered over in the name of regional economic integration. And the idea of ruling the country seems to have lost its appeal. So the armies, many with shrinking budgets, are now grappling to define their mission in the 1990's. Some of them have accepted Washington's offer of aid and training in return for joining the war on cocaine. Others are practicing the capitalism they long preached by running profitable businesses like transport companies, uniform manufacturers and gold mines.

headline.main: The World; Latin Armies Are Looking for Work

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT

docs.snippet: The Economy    A wave of new taxes and tax increases appears to be developing in states, counties and cities. The trend, the third wave of local taxes since the 1930's, shows up in the many taxes enacted last year or proposed for 1991. It is...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Economy A wave of new taxes and tax increases appears to be developing in states, counties and cities. The trend, the third wave of local taxes since the 1930's, shows up in the many taxes enacted last year or proposed for 1991. It is reflected in bitter debates over essential public services and it is seen in the willingness of three states without an income tax to consider one. [ Page A1. ]

docs.snippet: In this bustling town on the border of Brazil and Argentina, often called the Hong Kong of South America, smugglers fear that their long and lonely advocacy of free trade is about to become respectable.   On Tuesday, the Presidents of Argentina,...
docs.lead_paragraph: In this bustling town on the border of Brazil and Argentina, often called the Hong Kong of South America, smugglers fear that their long and lonely advocacy of free trade is about to become respectable. On Tuesday, the Presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay are to meet in Asuncion, Paraguay's capital, to sign a treaty forming the Southern Cone Common Market.

headline.main: Free Trade Fatefully Near For Paraguay's 'Hong Kong'

byline.original: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: The Presidents of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay have signed a agreement to build a common Latin American trading market. The Southern Common Market treaty, known as Mercosur, signed Tuesday, would dismantle trade barriers and encourage...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Presidents of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay have signed a agreement to build a common Latin American trading market. The Southern Common Market treaty, known as Mercosur, signed Tuesday, would dismantle trade barriers and encourage cross-border investment and joint projects over the next four years.

docs.snippet: Bora Milutinovic has taken English lessons for just two weeks, so he can't bark fiery commands at his new players. He doesn't know much about American soccer, or about dreary 1-0 losses to Bermuda and Switzerland.   But Milutinovic, named officially...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bora Milutinovic has taken English lessons for just two weeks, so he can't bark fiery commands at his new players. He doesn't know much about American soccer, or about dreary 1-0 losses to Bermuda and Switzerland. But Milutinovic, named officially yesterday as head coach of the United States national soccer team, is perhaps the only man anywhere who is virtually certain to be coaching at the 1994 World Cup. Conceptually, that counts for a great deal.

headline.main: A Confident Milutinovic Takes Over as U.S. Coach

docs.snippet: N.B.A.  Rockets Go Out Like Lambs: Having won all 13 of their games in March, the Houston Rockets had to like their chances of closing out an unbeaten month. After all, only two weak teams, Orlando and Miami, remained to be marched over in March. But...
docs.lead_paragraph: N.B.A. Rockets Go Out Like Lambs: Having won all 13 of their games in March, the Houston Rockets had to like their chances of closing out an unbeaten month. After all, only two weak teams, Orlando and Miami, remained to be marched over in March. But the Rockets stumbled against Orlando yesterday, being routed, 114-82, to fall short of becoming the first team in 18 years to be undefeated in a month. Orlando, playing at home, got 25 points and 14 assists from Scott Skiles and set three team defensive records: fewest points allowed in a quarter (12 in the first), fewest allowed in a game and lowest field-goal percentage by an opponent (30.7). (AP)

docs.snippet: Congress confronts two chances, one monumental, to boost prosperity through freer trade:   *The five-year Uruguay Round of international trade talks is, barring catastrophe, about to produce a reverberating agreement slashing trade barriers and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Congress confronts two chances, one monumental, to boost prosperity through freer trade: *The five-year Uruguay Round of international trade talks is, barring catastrophe, about to produce a reverberating agreement slashing trade barriers and thereby adding trillions to the world's economies by the year 2000.

docs.snippet: AT first everyone fell into a hush, and then they gawked as the black, sharp-angled F-117 Stealth fighter built in the United States streaked over a desert airstrip on the outskirts of Santiago like a strange Andean bird. It was the kickoff last...
docs.lead_paragraph: AT first everyone fell into a hush, and then they gawked as the black, sharp-angled F-117 Stealth fighter built in the United States streaked over a desert airstrip on the outskirts of Santiago like a strange Andean bird. It was the kickoff last month of Chile's 1992 International Air and Space Show, the pride of the Chilean military. Though the name may connote something less bellicose, the air show is the largest display in Latin America of technology and hardware to kill and wage war. Grenades, cluster bombs, Uzi submachine guns, artillery, radar systems, helicopter gunships and a host of fighter jets were on view. Generals, colonels and officers of indistinguishable rank mingled with arms vendors in a 10-day event that they hope will lead to multimillion dollar deals.

headline.main: Will More Guns for the Generals Aid or Threaten Democracy?

docs.snippet: Brazil and its commerical bankers announced an agreement yesterday for the country to retire $8 billion in unpaid interest.   The preliminary deal will open the way for the main round of the debt negotiations between Brazil and its bankers -- the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil and its commerical bankers announced an agreement yesterday for the country to retire $8 billion in unpaid interest. The preliminary deal will open the way for the main round of the debt negotiations between Brazil and its bankers -- the restructuring of $50 billion in borrowings that help make Brazil the largest debtor in the third world.

headline.main: Pact Reached On Brazil's Interest Debt

docs.snippet: To the Editor:   The new democratic Government of President Patricio Aylwin deserves all of the praise offered by your editorial "Encouraging Success in Chile" (March 19). Indeed, in many ways, Chile is emerging as a model for Latin America of both...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The new democratic Government of President Patricio Aylwin deserves all of the praise offered by your editorial "Encouraging Success in Chile" (March 19). Indeed, in many ways, Chile is emerging as a model for Latin America of both democracy and economic opportunity.

headline.main: Letter: On Latin America; Free-Trade Zone Is in Chile's Interest
